quiz.title: Unit 7: Imperfect Competition (Quiz 12)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Theory of the Firm, Costs, Efficiency, Market Power
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Short‑Run vs. Long‑Run Costs, Marginal Cost, Allocative Efficiency, Natural Monopoly, Price Discrimination, Non‑Price Competition, Oligopoly Barriers

questions.question: If the government were to set a price ceiling to get the socially optimal quantity in a natural monopoly, what would they have to do?
options: impose a tax on the firm
questions.explanation: A natural monopoly has decreasing ATC. Setting P = MC (socially optimal) yields P < ATC, causing losses. The government must subsidize the firm to keep it in operation.

questions.question: Which type of price discrimination charges each consumer the maximum they are willing to pay?
questions.explanation: First-degree (perfect) price discrimination involves charging each consumer exactly their reservation price, capturing all consumer surplus as producer surplus.

questions.question: What does marginal revenue equal when price discriminating?
questions.explanation: Under perfect (first-degree) price discrimination, the monopolist charges each consumer their willingness to pay, so the demand curve becomes the marginal revenue curve — MR = Demand.

questions.question: What is an example of non‑price competition?
questions.explanation: Non‑price competition includes advertising, branding, product features, customer service, and location advantages — strategies that compete on factors other than price.

questions.question: What is the economic profit of monopolistic competition in the long run?
questions.explanation: Due to free entry and exit, monopolistically competitive firms earn zero economic profit in the long run (P = ATC), though they produce where P > MC and have excess capacity.

questions.question: This is when firms can't legally work together, but are heavily influenced by other firms.
questions.explanation: Mutual interdependence occurs in oligopoly, where each firm's decisions affect others and are influenced by them, even without formal (illegal) collusion.

questions.question: All the following are typical barriers to entry in an Oligopoly, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Typical oligopoly barriers include economies of scale, high capital requirements, and control of resources. A high number of human capital (skilled labor) is not a barrier—it may actually lower entry costs.

questions.question:
True statements about the theory of the firm in the short run and long run include which of the following?
I. All input costs are fixed in the short run.
II. All input costs are variable in the long run.
III. At least one input price is fixed in the short run.
questions.explanation: In the short run, at least one input (e.g., capital) is fixed, but not all costs are fixed—some are variable. In the long run, all inputs can be varied, so all costs are variable. Thus, II and III are true.

questions.question: A firm’s short-run marginal cost curve will eventually increase because of
options: economies of scale (increasing returns to scale).
diseconomies of scale (decreasing returns to scale).
questions.explanation: In the short run, with at least one fixed input, adding more of a variable input eventually leads to diminishing marginal returns, causing marginal cost to rise.

questions.question: The condition for allocative efficiency is violated when
options: short-run profits exist in a competitive industry.
the market demand curve is inelastic in a competitive industry.
the market demand curve is elastic in a competitive industry.
questions.explanation: Allocative efficiency requires P = MC. Price-setting power (market power) allows P > MC, violating allocative efficiency and creating deadweight loss.
